title: Injury Risk Prediction Model
text: This page presents my DTSC 691 final project, a predictive model that estimates the risk of injury among U.S. Army trainees based on demographic and physical fitness characteristics.

title: Injury Risk Prediction Model
text:
1 Project Motivation
Injury prevention is a key priority in military readiness. Using simulated data that reflects real-world patterns in age, gender, and physical performance (measured by the ACFT), this model aims to identify trainees who may be at elevated injury risk.

title: Injury Risk Prediction Model
text:
2 Modeling Approach

Target Variable: Binary indicator of whether a trainee was injured.
Predictors:

Age (standardized)
Gender
ACFT performance (Pass/Fail)

Model Type: Binary logistic regression model
Performance Metric: Area Under the ROC Curve (AUC)

title: Injury Risk Prediction Model
text:
3 Results

AUC: 0.641
Optimal Classification Threshold: ~0.135
Top predictors: Age, gender, and failing ACFT


3.1 Predicted Injury Probability Distribution



Predicted Injury Probability Distribution




3.2 Example Prediction Output
You can interact with the live model below or open it in a new tab:
Open Injury Prediction Model

title: Welcome
text:
Welcome to my Data Science Portfolio. I’m an epidemiologist, data scientist, and public health leader with a passion for translating complex data into actionable insights that drive meaningful change.







I am currently completing my Master of Science in Data Science and Analytics at Eastern University, with expected graduation in July 2025.
My academic journey also includes:

Doctor of Public Health, Capella University (2016)

Master of Public Health, Purdue University Global (2012)

Bachelor of Science, Elizabeth City State University (2002)




I aspire to continue advancing in the field of data science for public health, particularly in roles that blend epidemiology, predictive modeling, and health systems innovation. My long-term goal is to lead efforts that improve public health infrastructure using AI and machine learning.




Injury prevention and surveillance

Health data analytics

Machine learning and predictive modeling

Natural language processing

Health equity and access to care




When I’m not deep in a dataset or building predictive models, I enjoy mentoring emerging public health professionals and volunteering with community-based organizations like Season to Soar. I also love baking, traveling, and spending time with my family in Suffolk, Virginia.
This website highlights a few of my academic and professional projects, including an interactive Injury Risk Prediction Shiny Application built for my graduate capstone.

title: Featured Projects
text:
Visit Website ›
I serve as the Project Coordinator at Season to Soar, a nonprofit organization supporting underserved youth. I developed and manage the organization’s website and technical infrastructure.

Our most recent project was the Global Youth Leadership Panel, which brought together students and global changemakers for dialogue and development.

title: Featured Projects
text:
Educational Justice Institute (EJI)
Visit Website ›
As Director of Technology Initiatives, I built and maintain the EJI website, which supports K–12 students, educators, and researchers. This platform provides access to educational equity tools, journals, and programs.

title: Featured Projects
text:
CDC NCHS Data Query System
Launch Tool ›
At the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, I support a team of data analysts and statisticians in developing scalable public data tools. I contributed to the creation of the NCHS Data Query System, which allows users to interactively explore health statistics and custom reports.

title: Featured Projects
text:
CDC Publication – Vaccination Coverage Study
Read Publication ›
As a CDC epidemiologist, I co-authored a study on vaccination coverage and exemption rates among kindergarteners in the U.S. This work supported national immunization strategies and informed state-level policy.
